p: I. cylindrica’s extracts are also known for their anti-inflammatory activities [ 191], which can be attributed to isoeugenin ( Table S1), isolated from the methanol extract of this species’ roots. This compound was tested against macrophages (RAW264.7 cells) and showed significant activity (IC 50 9.33 µg/mL) in suppressing expressions at the mRNA (messenger ribonucleic acid) level of nitric oxide synthase (iNOS), cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) and proinflammatory cytokines [ 87]. Choi and co-workers (2017), conducted in vivo and in vitro assays to evaluate the anti-inflammatory activity of L. multiflorum methanol extract [ 192]. They concluded that this activity involves the suppression of NF-κB DNA-binding activation through inhibition of ERK (extracellular-signal-regulated kinase) and p38 MAPK ( mitogen-activated protein kinase) phosphorylation. Although the polar components of this species are not well known, the activity could be related to ferulic acid [ 98], present in the polar extracts of L. multiflorum [ 84]
